The shrill trompettes sounde th' allaram loude;</br>The gallant Knightys in armour rich bedighte</br>Enter the lystes, ymounted high on horses proude,</br>Prank'd in boss'd harnyss, neighying for the fyght.
The heraulds tall, in purfled mantyls cladde,</br>In quanynte devyces wroughte (by connynge honde)</br>Of knyghtlie chevisaunces long since hadde,</br>With caytive paynim in the haly londe,
Proclayme with loude voyce the courteous fyghte;</br>Whyle evir and anon the cornets sounde,</br>And pleasaunt layes pronounced by ladyes bryghte,</br>And cheerynge mynshelsie are hearde arounde.

High seats, and gaye pavyllions cirque the place,</br>Where royal dames and damosels faire are seen,</br>With princelie lordes, of highe descent and grace,</br>And courtlie youth, and hoarie eld, I weene.
Alofte in ayre, the silken banners fly;</br>The postes with scutcheons of pretence are hong;</br>The streamers in the buxome welkin playe,</br>And lyttle banderoles here and theare are flong.

Hearke!  hearke!  a hondredde brazen trompettes braye!</br>The charge!  the charge!  a thousande voyces crye;</br>The fomynge steedes rush forwarde to the fraye;—</br>The clutterynge armoure ryngs — the broken launces flye.
But who ys he, ycased in hauberque bryghte?</br>Hys scalie greaves with golden owches boss'd—</br>Hys polished marion dazzles humaine syghte—</br>Hys loftie plumasse by the wynde is toss'd?

Hys milk whyte horse, yprauncing tears the grownde,</br>And champes the bytte, and shakes hys flowynge mayne;</br>He snorts, and flyngs hys foame arownde,</br>Throwes hyghe his hedde, and scorns the curbed rayne!</br>
